summary.topic: i started making videos as a kid, inspired by my sister's youtube
summary.summary: started doing videos as a kid after seeing my sister make YouTube videos. thought I could do better, grabbed her camera, and started making my own around age eight or nine.

summary.topic: i began with youtube videos, then moved to music videos, weddings, and corporate videos
summary.summary: started shooting music videos, weddings, corporate videos, and small client stuff, which led me here. to make a good video, many things matter like the story and...

summary.topic: a good video involves open discussion and many elements like storytelling and cinematography
summary.summary: curiosity gap seems like the main thing, not just one single aspect like cinematography. the story name carries a lot of weight too.

summary.topic: curiosity gap is essential depending on your creation intention
summary.summary: depends on what you intend to create. engaging the

summary.topic: engagement is critical in making a good video
summary.summary: engaging, yeah. there are many things that make a good video. all your answers are correct, but here are my four basic fundamentals of what makes a good video: it's one.

summary.topic: focus on storytelling, basic techniques, and different types of storytelling we'll cover later
summary.summary: storytelling and basic techniques we'll cover later include types you can use on platforms like instagram, tiktok, youtube, or a blog. we'll also discuss the workflow.

summary.topic: the workflow includes the process of getting an idea into a video format
summary.summary: the building blocks of video creation start with an idea and translating it into video format. starting out, focus on the feeling rather than technical aspects like hooks. in the beginning, it's all about capturing that initial inspiration.

summary.topic: when starting out, focus on making videos that feel good to you
summary.summary: when i was a kid, i made videos using hypercam to record counter-strike gameplay. i didn't care about the intro or ending, just wanted the video to feel good to me, so i made it with some good music behind it.

summary.topic: videos can evoke various emotions like laughter, motivation, and more
summary.summary: if you're not deep into the video-making side and just want to showcase your product, focus on making content that feels good to you. videos can evoke emotions like laughter, tears, or motivation, and can drive actions. think about how you feel after watching a movie – that's the kind of impact you want.

summary.topic: make videos that you would want to watch yourself
summary.summary: watched what were you watching cool cool okay i haven't watched that yet i gotta watch it yeah anybody else hype hype what was that what video made you hype

summary.topic: avoid overthinking and just focus on creating something enjoyable
summary.summary: even pictures can evoke feelings and inspire actions. if you're making a video, especially with limited time left, ensure it's something you'd want to watch yourself. many are scrambling to put out content, but the key is to focus on creating videos you genuinely like, rather than just chasing numbers. good videos are about more than just hooks and content.

summary.topic: two types of videos are timeless and memes
summary.summary: there are two types of videos you guys could probably make and see all the time: timeless and memes. it's all about a feeling.

summary.topic: timeless videos are those you can revisit anytime for inspiration
summary.summary: i always go back to watch casey neistat's timeless video when i'm lost and trying to make a banger video. it gives me a good framework despite being shot on a small camera. another example of a timeless video is by natalie lynn, emphasizing the transient nature of life and its beauty, connecting deeply with viewers.

summary.topic: memes are tied to a generational time period or current trends
summary.summary: memes reflect generational trends and familiarity that prompt participation. they serve a purpose, be it humorous or serious, and the best ones balance familiarity with novelty. the key is to focus on what you're trying to communicate and find the right style to convey that message effectively.

summary.topic: hyperfocus on your message and choose the right style, whether timeless or meme
summary.summary: she had just a few hundred followers and decided to try something she enjoyed, like the "dear stranger" concept. experimenting with various content, including templates and other people's ideas, she gradually developed her own style. the key takeaway is to try different types of content to find what works best for your message, as blindly copying others won't necessarily yield the same results.

summary.topic: don't worry about making original videos; many templates and inspirations already exist
summary.summary: don't bother trying to make an original video. others have already paved the way for you. just use existing videos as templates, and you'll find plenty of them on platforms like IG and TikTok.

summary.topic: use platforms like IG and TikTok for templates and inspiration
summary.summary: use green screen videos or mimic videos you like for inspiration. add context, like captions for audio, to improve the video quality. learn from examples, like carol crafts' videos, but add your own style and keep your wording simple and clear. iterate on your voice and style to find what works for you.

summary.topic: good music is a crucial hack that many overlook in video creation
summary.summary: choosing the right music is a practical, often overlooked hack for creating better videos. for example, the powerful soundtrack of the movie oppenheimer can inspire viewers to want to create their own music. good music can elevate the entire experience of a video.

summary.topic: music sets the mood and guides the type of video you make
summary.summary: making videos with specific soundtracks can elevate them by evoking certain emotions. having a good music catalog and understanding how instruments affect feelings can guide the type of content you create. at build space, many video ideas come from music, often working backwards from a track that inspires us.

summary.topic: a good soundtrack can influence ideas and the overall feel of the video
summary.summary: we made a video using the song "opener" because it was trending. we watched it repeatedly to get inspired, deciding to base the video around jeffrey scrolling through stuff before playing the music. picking the right song helps guide the video's creation; using familiar tracks like 90s rap or iconic songs can create an instant connection with viewers. choose music that matches your video's pace and style to enhance its impact.

summary.topic: organize your footage chronologically and match it with appropriate music
summary.summary: decide whether the music influences the video or the video influences the music. the speaker prefers choosing the music first. they emphasize understanding rhythm and beats to appreciate music more deeply, mentioning that some people don't listen with musical inclination.

summary.topic: experiment with both timeless and meme content to find what fits your style
summary.summary: pick good music for your videos, especially if you want them to go viral. use music that people know and like, but make sure it fits the video's content. focus on color grading, sound effects, vocals, and music to make your videos stand out. develop a workflow for your video process and don't ignore small details; they can make a big difference.

summary.topic: finalize your video process by scriptwriting with proper pacing
summary.summary: we keep it basic and avoid writing whole essays. i narrate to maintain good pacing, ensuring the videos fit naturally when edited. i focus on what's available to shoot immediately to streamline the workflow, allowing easy integration of footage into the script and minor iterations as needed. i draft quickly for team feedback to refine the content.

summary.topic: feedback and minor iterations help refine your video
summary.summary: i'm bad at this myself but i try not to overthink it. some of you, like samy, ask me what you should do differently for a video, but if it's a banger, don't overdo it. consider if the effort to make changes is really worth it or if you can just post and move on to the next thing.

summary.topic: don't overcomplicate; the key is to keep creating and sharing
summary.summary: just go make something for yourself. that's all for today. if you have any questions, let me know.
